---
title: Spread
---



<div id="the-spread-function" class="section level1">
<h1>The <code>spread()</code> Function</h1>
<p>The first <code>tidyr</code> function we will look into is the <code>spread()</code> function. With <code>spread()</code> it does similar to what you would expect. We have a data frame where some of the rows contain information that is really a variable name. This means the columns are a combination of variable names as well as some data. The picture below displays this:</p>
<div class="figure">
<img src="data:image/png;base64," />

</div>
<p>We can consider the following data which is table 2:</p>
<pre><code>## # A tibble: 12 × 4
##        country  year        key      value
##         &lt;fctr&gt; &lt;int&gt;     &lt;fctr&gt;      &lt;int&gt;
## 1  Afghanistan  1999      cases        745
## 2  Afghanistan  1999 population   19987071
## 3  Afghanistan  2000      cases       2666
## 4  Afghanistan  2000 population   20595360
## 5       Brazil  1999      cases      37737
## 6       Brazil  1999 population  172006362
## 7       Brazil  2000      cases      80488
## 8       Brazil  2000 population  174504898
## 9        China  1999      cases     212258
## 10       China  1999 population 1272915272
## 11       China  2000      cases     213766
## 12       China  2000 population 1280428583</code></pre>
<p>Notice that in the column of <code>key</code>, instead of there being values we see the following variable names:</p>
<ul>
<li>cases</li>
<li>population</li>
</ul>
<p>In order to use this data we need to have it so the data frame looks like this instead:</p>
<pre><code>## # A tibble: 6 × 4
##       country  year  cases population
## *      &lt;fctr&gt; &lt;int&gt;  &lt;int&gt;      &lt;int&gt;
## 1 Afghanistan  1999    745   19987071
## 2 Afghanistan  2000   2666   20595360
## 3      Brazil  1999  37737  172006362
## 4      Brazil  2000  80488  174504898
## 5       China  1999 212258 1272915272
## 6       China  2000 213766 1280428583</code></pre>
<p>Now we can see that we have all the columns representing the variables we are interested in and each of the rows is now a complete observation.</p>
<p>In order to do this we need to learn about the <code>spread()</code> function:</p>
<pre><code>spread(data, key, value)</code></pre>
<p>Where</p>
<ul>
<li><code>data</code> is your dataframe of interest.</li>
<li><code>key</code> is the column whose values will become variable names.</li>
<li><code>value</code> is the column where values will fill in under the new variables created from <code>key</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>If we consider <strong>piping</strong>, we can write this as:</p>
<pre><code>data %&gt;%
  spread(key, value)</code></pre>
<div id="spread-example" class="section level2">
<h2><code>spread()</code> Example</h2>
<p>Now if we consider table2 , we can see that we have:</p>
<pre><code>## # A tibble: 12 × 4
##        country  year        key      value
##         &lt;fctr&gt; &lt;int&gt;     &lt;fctr&gt;      &lt;int&gt;
## 1  Afghanistan  1999      cases        745
## 2  Afghanistan  1999 population   19987071
## 3  Afghanistan  2000      cases       2666
## 4  Afghanistan  2000 population   20595360
## 5       Brazil  1999      cases      37737
## 6       Brazil  1999 population  172006362
## 7       Brazil  2000      cases      80488
## 8       Brazil  2000 population  174504898
## 9        China  1999      cases     212258
## 10       China  1999 population 1272915272
## 11       China  2000      cases     213766
## 12       China  2000 population 1280428583</code></pre>
<p>Now this table was made for this example so key is the <code>key</code> in our <code>spread()</code> function and value is the <code>value</code> in our <code>spread()</code> function. We can fix this with the following code:</p>
<pre class="r"><code>table2 %&gt;%
    spread(key,value)</code></pre>
<pre><code>## # A tibble: 6 × 4
##       country  year  cases population
## *      &lt;fctr&gt; &lt;int&gt;  &lt;int&gt;      &lt;int&gt;
## 1 Afghanistan  1999    745   19987071
## 2 Afghanistan  2000   2666   20595360
## 3      Brazil  1999  37737  172006362
## 4      Brazil  2000  80488  174504898
## 5       China  1999 212258 1272915272
## 6       China  2000 213766 1280428583</code></pre>
<p>We can now see that we have a variable named <code>cases</code> and a variable named <code>population</code>. This is much most tidy.</p>
<div class="content-box-green">
<h1>
On Your Own: RStudio Practice
</h1>
<p>We first will load tidyverse. If you have not installed it run the following code:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>install.packages(&quot;tidyverse&quot;)</code></li>
</ul>
<p>Then load this package:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>library(tidyverse)</code></li>
</ul>
<p>In this example we will use the dataset <code>population</code> that is part of tidyverse. Print this data:</p>
<pre><code>## # A tibble: 1 × 3
##       country  year population
##         &lt;chr&gt; &lt;int&gt;      &lt;int&gt;
## 1 Afghanistan  1995   17586073</code></pre>
<p>You should see the table that we have above, now We have a variable named <code>year</code>, assume that we wish to actually have each year as its own variable. Using the <code>spread()</code> function, redo this data so that each year is a variable. Your data will look like this at the end:</p>
<pre><code>## # A tibble: 219 × 20
##                country   `1995`   `1996`   `1997`   `1998`   `1999`
## *                &lt;chr&gt;    &lt;int&gt;    &lt;int&gt;    &lt;int&gt;    &lt;int&gt;    &lt;int&gt;
## 1          Afghanistan 17586073 18415307 19021226 19496836 19987071
## 2              Albania  3357858  3341043  3331317  3325456  3317941
## 3              Algeria 29315463 29845208 30345466 30820435 31276295
## 4       American Samoa    52874    53926    54942    55899    56768
## 5              Andorra    63854    64274    64090    63799    64084
## 6               Angola 12104952 12451945 12791388 13137542 13510616
## 7             Anguilla     9807    10063    10305    10545    10797
## 8  Antigua and Barbuda    68349    70245    72232    74206    76041
## 9            Argentina 34833168 35264070 35690778 36109342 36514558
## 10             Armenia  3223173  3173425  3137652  3112958  3093820
## # ... with 209 more rows, and 14 more variables: `2000` &lt;int&gt;,
## #   `2001` &lt;int&gt;, `2002` &lt;int&gt;, `2003` &lt;int&gt;, `2004` &lt;int&gt;, `2005` &lt;int&gt;,
## #   `2006` &lt;int&gt;, `2007` &lt;int&gt;, `2008` &lt;int&gt;, `2009` &lt;int&gt;, `2010` &lt;int&gt;,
## #   `2011` &lt;int&gt;, `2012` &lt;int&gt;, `2013` &lt;int&gt;</code></pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>




</div>

<script>

// add bootstrap table styles to pandoc tables
function bootstrapStylePandocTables() {
  $('tr.header').parent('thead').parent('table').addClass('table table-condensed');
}
$(document).ready(function () {
  bootstrapStylePandocTables();
});


</script>
